title: Former judge calls for relatives of Essex lorry victims to be granted UK entry
text:
A retired judge has called for the families of the 39 people who died in a lorry to be allowed into the UK so they can be fully involved in investigations and inquests into the deaths of their loved ones.

Catriona Jarvis, formerly a judge in the upper tribunal of the immigration and asylum chamber, is co-convenor of the Last Rights project, which works to protect the rights of missing and dead migrants and their bereaved families.

As postmortem examinations begin, the focus is turning to the investigatory process. Jarvis welcomed efforts from the National Crime Agency to identify the 39 people and trace their families but said the bereaved families should be fully involved with the investigation.

“We should be working with the families, not putting obstacles in their way,” she said. “They should be issued with visas to come to the UK and they should have access to legal advice. We are calling for support to be put in place for families once everyone in the lorry has been identified so they can participate fully in the investigations.”

She expressed concern about the response of the home secretary, Priti Patel, who said she would consider stronger penalties against smugglers.

Jarvis said: “It’s woefully insufficient to call for greater sentences. I don’t think Priti Patel’s approach is realistic. We need to look at the reasons why people are moving as well as at exploitation by smugglers or traffickers. We need to look at both at the same time.”

Jarvis advocated mechanisms to allow migrants to be able to travel without putting their lives at risk. “We need safe passage and humanitarian visas so that people will no longer need to make these terrible and dangerous journeys,” she said.

She also expressed concern about information that had been publicly circulated about where the lorry may have travelled from. When Bulgaria was mentioned, many people with relatives who have passed through that country in hope of reaching the UK became frantically worried their family member had been in the lorry where the 39 Chinese nationals were discovered.

“Inaccurate information in the public domain adds to people’s trauma,” she said.

Jarvis and others were instrumental in drawing up the landmark Mytilini Declaration document, which was signed on the island of Lesbos in May 2018. It establishes the rights of and duties towards all those who experience suffering because of the death or disappearance of their loved ones as a consequence of migrant journeys.

“We are working to create a more respectful legal framework for the rights of dead migrants,” Jarvis said. “We need to look at things through the eyes of the bereaved.”

In December 2018, the UN Compact for Safe and Orderly Migration was signed by many countries. It is a commitment to provide better treatment for migrants and includes an objective that states are required to save lives, prevent deaths and injuries to migrants, identify the missing and the dead and provide assistance to their families.

Deborah Coles, director of the charity Inquest, echoed Jarvis’s call for full involvement of the bereaved families in investigations into the deaths.

Coles said: “This is a shocking, shameful and avoidable loss of life. Both the individual deaths and the broader social and political context must be subject to the most searching scrutiny in a process which enables the bereaved families to participate.”

Jarvis added: “We can’t just say this is a crime and leave it at that. We want to ensure that we respect the dead and their families in the same way we would wish to happen for our families and loved ones.”
